awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Modulation of the Presynaptic Action Potential Shape and  Impact on Synaptic Function
awd_abstract_narration:
Everything animals see and do is controlled by electrical signals in their nerves and muscle. Ion channels, which function like tiny pores in the cell membrane, are crucial for sensing and generating electrical signals. The synaptic terminal connections between brain cells are where electrical signals initiate the release of neurotransmitters. Identifying the ion channels present at nerve terminals holds great promise for the development of future therapeutics. Measuring ion channels at nerve terminals is difficult due to their small size. The investigator has recently developed sensitive optical approaches that allow the measurement of electrical signals in nerve terminals with light. The goals of this project are to utilize this optical approach to: (1) identify ion channel compositions within nerve fibers crucial for sensing and generating electrical signals; (2) understand how the changing electrical signals alters synaptic communication; as well as (3) promote the understanding and use of quantitative fluorescent microscopy across undergraduate institutions in New Hampshire to foster innovation in the research workforce. 

Transfer of an electrical signal from one neuron to another (i.e. synaptic transmission) typically involves rapid depolarization of the presynaptic terminal, the entry of calcium ions, membrane fusion of vesicles that contain neurotransmitter signaling to the postsynaptic neuron.  This sequence is set in motion by a rapid membrane depolarization, or action potential (AP), invading the presynaptic terminal. AP shape has often been ignored as a malleable signal at the subcellular level and is assumed to propagate as a uniform spike across thousands of synaptic contacts.  This project will challenge this perception of the AP as an unchanging "all-or-none" waveform and address a fundamental gap in the understanding of axon physiology and synaptic transmission. The central hypothesis of this project is that after initiation, an AP is malleable and undergoes local "sculpting" during propagation throughout the axonal arborization, and this consequentially impacts presynaptic function. The investigator has developed sensitive optical approaches that allow the quantification of changes in membrane voltage using light that bypasses previous technical barriers to measure voltage in small cellular compartments such as the axon.  Using these genetically encoded voltage indicators the PI will: (1) Determine how and where an AP is sculpted along the axon and pre-synaptic terminals; (2) Determine how AP shape drives calcium influx and activation of calcium sensors at the molecular level to impact vesicle fusion, using a combination of quantitative optical sensors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our bodies are controlled by electricity. The musculature, endocrine and nervous systems rely on precise electrical signaling to operate. Voltage-sensitive pores in the cell membrane known as ion channels generate, transmit, sense and sculpt electrical signals at the cellular level. Transient electrical impulses called action potentials (AP) are the essential communicative units that enable rapid signaling at synaptic contacts between neurons. The long slender signaling projection (axon) of a neuron, when seen under a microscope, is abundantly decorated with specialized swellings called presynaptic bouton. Presynaptic boutons are full of organelles, the majority of which are packets of chemical neurotransmitter called vesicles. The arrival of an AP in a presynaptic bouton triggers an influx of calcium and the fusion of vesicles which release chemical neurotransmitter activating connected neurons. Changing the magnitude of this cellular activation evoked by an AP is what underlies learning and memory, and impairments in this process are associated with several neurological diseases. Over the last three decades a great deal has been learned about the molecular machinery of vesicle fusion. In contrast, much less is known about the distribution and properties of ion channels which sculpt the synaptic AP that initiates and modulates the strength of synaptic transmission. My laboratory’s research seeks to identify the organization, function, and therapeutic potential for ion channels and their binding partners for regulating synaptic transmission. Ion channel research was propelled by the invention of glass electrodes to precisely measure electrical signals in cell membranes. However, the average neuron in a human brain sends electrical signals across axons that are only 1/1000th the width of a human hair while also sometimes spanning over a meter in total length. Progress in the field of neurobiology has been stymied by the fact that the axon is far too small and delicate for measuring ion channel function with electrodes in most common synaptic terminals.

 

My laboratory at Dartmouth focuses on devising and refining optical techniques to measure ion channel activity using genetically-encoded optical indicators to overcome these size barriers in the axon and terminals. We take a reductionist approach to answer these questions regarding synaptic transmission and ion channel function using quantitative microscopy in cultured neurons. This preparation allows us to ask very precise molecular questions thanks to the optical and genetic accessibility.

 

The support of this funding from the NSF allowed us to use optical voltage measurements to identify and measure action potentials for the first time at the subcellular level.  This accomplished three major goals.  First, we found that APs are not purely spikes that digitally turn synapses on or off, but that they encode information in their spike waveform that powerfully modulate the strength of synaptic communication upstream of vesicle fusion machinery, primarily regulated by voltage-gated sodium and potassium channels, that are uniquely regulated in subcellular regions of the axon. Second, this funding allowed us to help create new optical indicators of calcium and glutamate that identified regulators of synaptic plasticity as well as imaging in more complex systems ex vivo and in vivo.  This allowed us to explore of a second pathway of neurotransmitter release known as spontaneous vesicle fusion. We found that the frequency of spontaneous release displays significant heterogeneity and is directly related to synaptic strength that acts as an important signaling mechanism to the postsynaptic neuron at individual synapses. Finally, thanks to this funding, we were able to make simultaneous measurement of synaptic transmission and membrane voltage, which has revealed a small cadre of non-conducting ion channels that support synaptic transmission. 

Going forward, this grant funding laid the framework for us to continue our study of ion channel interacting proteins in the axon and synapse to expand this novel molecular network. We will accomplish this using a combination of candidate genetics and subcellular proximity proteomics to extend our knowledge of axon/synapse-specific ion channel regulators. These studies will not only augment our understanding of mechanisms for modulating APs, but also identify non-canonical ion channel functions for tethering or localizing proteins within the axon and synapse. Taken together, this will enhance our understanding of neurological function and underlying foundation of memory formation.  

 

The broader impacts of this award are at many levels. First, this grant produced 13 peer-reviewed publications, including 7 as corresponding author, that have been cited 281 times to date. Second, this grant helped train 9 undergraduate students, four of whom are attending or completed graduate school, and 4 in medical school. This grant also supported the training of three graduate students and three postdoctoral fellows who have continued in science. Third, we have strengthened connections with several primarily undergraduate institutions in NH through seminars and invitations to a new multi-institutional Neuroscience Day held annually at Dartmouth.
